Limit law of a second class particle in TASEP with non-random initial condition

P.L. Ferrari Institute for Applied Mathematics, Bonn University, Endenicher Allee 60, 53115 Bonn, Germany. E-mail: ferrari@uni-bonn.de    P. Ghosal Columbia University, Department of Statistics, 1255 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10027, USA. E-mail: pg2475@columbia.edu    P. Nejjar IST Austria, Am Campus 1, 3400 Klosterneuburg, Austria. Partially supported by ERC Advanced Grant No. 338804 and ERC Starting Grant No. 716117, E-mail: peter.nejjar@ist.ac.at
(May 22, 2018)
Abstract

We consider the totally asymmetric simple exclusion process (TASEP) with non-random initial condition and density λ𝜆\lambda on ℤ−subscriptℤ\mathbb{Z}_{-} and ρ𝜌\rho on ℤ+subscriptℤ\mathbb{Z}_{+}, and a second class particle initially at the origin. For λ<ρ𝜆𝜌\lambda<\rho, there is a shock and the second class particle moves with speed 1−λ−ρ1𝜆𝜌1-\lambda-\rho. For large time t𝑡t, we show that the position of the second class particle fluctuates on the t1/3superscript𝑡13t^{1/3} scale and determine its limiting law. We also obtain the limiting distribution of the number of steps made by the second class particle until time t𝑡t.

1 Introduction and main result

The totally asymmetric simple exclusion process (TASEP) is one of the simplest non-reversible interacting particle systems on ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} lattice. A TASEP particle configuration is described by the occupation variables {ηj}j∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝜂𝑗𝑗ℤ\{\eta_{j}\}_{j\in\mathbb{Z}} where ηj=1subscript𝜂𝑗1\eta_{j}=1 means site j𝑗j is occupied by a particle and ηj=0subscript𝜂𝑗0\eta_{j}=0 means site j𝑗j is empty. The TASEP dynamics are as follows. Particles jump one step to the right and are allowed to do so only if their right neighboring site is empty. Jumps are independent of each other and are performed after an exponential waiting time with mean 111, which starts from the time instant when the right neighbor site is empty.

More precisely, denoting by η∈𝒮={0,1}ℤ𝜂𝒮superscript01ℤ\eta\in{\cal S}=\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{Z}} a configuration, the infinitesimal generator of TASEP is given by the closure of the operator L𝐿L

L​f​(η)=∑j∈ℤηj​(1−ηj+1)​(f​(ηj,j+1)−f​(η)),𝐿𝑓𝜂subscript𝑗ℤsubscript𝜂𝑗1subscript𝜂𝑗1𝑓superscript𝜂𝑗𝑗1𝑓𝜂Lf(\eta)=\sum_{j\in\mathbb{Z}}\eta_{j}(1-\eta_{j+1})(f(\eta^{j,j+1})-f(\eta)), (1.1)

where f:𝒮→ℝ:𝑓→𝒮ℝf:{\cal S}\to\mathbb{R} is any function depending on finitely many ηjsubscript𝜂𝑗\eta_{j}’s, and ηj,j+1superscript𝜂𝑗𝑗1\eta^{j,j+1} is the configuration η𝜂\eta with the occupation variables at sites j𝑗j and j+1𝑗1j+1 interchanged. The semigroup eL​tsuperscript𝑒𝐿𝑡e^{Lt} is well-defined as acting on bounded and continuous functions on 𝒮𝒮{\cal S}, see [25] for further details on the construction. Since particles can not overtake each other, we can associate a labeling to them and denote the position of particle k𝑘k at time t𝑡t by xk​(t)subscript𝑥𝑘𝑡x_{k}(t). We choose the right-to-left ordering, namely, we have xk+1​(0)<xk​(0)subscript𝑥𝑘10subscript𝑥𝑘0x_{k+1}(0)<x_{k}(0) for any k𝑘k.

The observable we study in this paper is the so-called second class particle. The only difference between a particle described above (also called first class particle) with a second class particle is the following: when a first class particle tries to jump on a site occupied by a second class particle, the jump is not suppressed and the two particles interchanges their positions. Second class particles can be also seen as discrepancies between two TASEP systems coupled by the basic coupling, see e.g. [26], starting from p.218, for further details. For instance, consider two TASEP configurations η,η′∈𝒮𝜂superscript𝜂′𝒮\eta,\eta^{\prime}\in{\cal S} which at time 00 differ only at the site 00. Then under basic coupling the two configurations will differ only at one site for any time t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0, and we can define

Xt=∑x∈ℤx​𝟙{ηt​(x)≠ηt′​(x)}.subscript𝑋𝑡subscript𝑥ℤ𝑥subscript1subscript𝜂𝑡𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝜂′𝑡𝑥X_{t}=\sum_{x\in\mathbb{Z}}x\mathbbm{1}_{\{\eta_{t}(x)\neq\eta^{\prime}_{t}(x)\}}. (1.2)

to be the position of the second class particle at time t𝑡t. From this perspective, the distribution of Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t} gives an information on the correlation between ηj​(t)subscript𝜂𝑗𝑡\eta_{j}(t) and η0​(0)subscript𝜂00\eta_{0}(0). For the case of the stationary initial condition, where every site is independently occupied with probability ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho, the law of the second class particle is precisely proportional to Cov​(ηj​(t),η0​(0))Covsubscript𝜂𝑗𝑡subscript𝜂00{\rm Cov}(\eta_{j}(t),\eta_{0}(0)), see e.g. [31].

Second class particle are also very useful when the interacting system generates shocks, which are discontinuities in the particle density. Indeed, the position of the shock can be identified with Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t}, see Chapter 3 of [26]. For that reason already several studies are devoted to the second class particles. For instance, consider a single second class particle starting at the origin. For TASEP initial condition is Bernoulli product measure with density λ𝜆\lambda on ℤ−={…,−3,−2,−1}subscriptℤ…321\mathbb{Z}_{-}=\{\ldots,-3,-2,-1\} and density ρ𝜌\rho on ℤ+={1,2,3,…}subscriptℤ123…\mathbb{Z}_{+}=\{1,2,3,\ldots\} with λ<ρ𝜆𝜌\lambda<\rho. Then Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t} moves with an average speed of 1−ρ−λ1𝜌𝜆1-\rho-\lambda and it has Gaussian fluctuations on a t1/2superscript𝑡12t^{1/2} scale [9, 10, 22, 12]. For shocks created by deterministic initial data, [17] obtained the limit law of a first class particle located at the shock. Later, multipoint distributions of several particles at the shock where obtained [18], and the transition to shock fluctuations was studied [28]. For the case λ<ρ𝜆𝜌\lambda<\rho, what remained open is the limit law of the second class particle Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t}, and this is what we obtain in this paper.

When the initial condition is product Bernoulli measure with λ𝜆\lambda on ℤ−subscriptℤ\mathbb{Z}_{-} and ρ𝜌\rho on ℤ+subscriptℤ\mathbb{Z}_{+} with λ>ρ𝜆𝜌\lambda>\rho, a second class particle placed initially at the origin chooses one direction uniformly among its characteristics and then moves at a constant speed along that direction [11, 27]. This means that the fluctuations of the second class particle are of order t𝑡t. Tightly related with the trajectory of the second class particle is the notion of competition interface in a last passage percolation model introduced in [13] for λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1 and ρ=0𝜌0\rho=0. This connection was later extended for more general cases in [12]. They prove that for any initial conditions with asymptotically density λ<ρ𝜆𝜌\lambda<\rho to the left and right of the origin respectively, a second class particle moves along a characteristics, chosen according to a random distribution which depends on the initial condition. However only for the Bernoulli initial condition is the precise distribution known.

For constant density results on the fluctuations of the second class particle are known only for the stationary case. Using coupling arguments it was shown in [5] that the fluctuation scale of the second class particle is t2/3superscript𝑡23t^{2/3} (by controlling some moments). The exact limiting distribution has been obtained in [20].

Main result

In this paper we also consider TASEP with initial density λ𝜆\lambda on ℤ−subscriptℤ\mathbb{Z}_{-} and ρ𝜌\rho on ℤ+subscriptℤ\mathbb{Z}_{+}, λ<ρ𝜆𝜌\lambda<\rho, but this time without initial randomness. More precisely, we start with TASEP particles at

xn​(0)subscript𝑥𝑛0\displaystyle x_{n}(0) =−⌊λ−1​n⌋absentsuperscript𝜆1𝑛\displaystyle=-\left\lfloor\lambda^{-1}n\right\rfloor when ​n>0,when 𝑛0\displaystyle\quad\text{when }n>0, (1.3)
xn​(0)subscript𝑥𝑛0\displaystyle x_{n}(0) =−⌊ρ−1​n⌋absentsuperscript𝜌1𝑛\displaystyle=-\left\lfloor\rho^{-1}n\right\rfloor when ​n<0,when 𝑛0\displaystyle\quad\text{when }n<0,

and one second class particle at the origin, X0=0subscript𝑋00X_{0}=0. Our main result, Theorem 1.1, concerns the joint limiting distribution of Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t} and of Ntsubscript𝑁𝑡N_{t}, where the latter being the number of steps made by the second class particle until time t𝑡t.

Theorem 1.1.

Consider TASEP with initial condition (1.3), where 0<λ<ρ<1,0𝜆𝜌10<\lambda<\rho<1, and a second class particle at 00 at time t=0𝑡0t=0. Let Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t} be the second class particle’s position at time t𝑡t, and let Ntsubscript𝑁𝑡N_{t} be the number of steps it made up to time t𝑡t. Then, we have convergence in distribution

(Xt−𝐯​tt1/3,Nt−2​μ0−1​tt1/3)⇒(𝒳,𝒩)⇒subscript𝑋𝑡𝐯𝑡superscript𝑡13subscript𝑁𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝜇01𝑡superscript𝑡13𝒳𝒩\left(\frac{X_{t}-\mathbf{v}t}{t^{1/3}},\frac{N_{t}-2\mu_{0}^{-1}t}{t^{1/3}}\right)\Rightarrow(\mathcal{X},\mathcal{N}) (1.4)

as t→∞→𝑡t\to\infty, where

𝒳=21/3μ04/3​Υ​(σ1​ξGOE(1)ρ​(1−ρ)−σ2​ξGOE(2)λ​(1−λ)),𝒳superscript213subscriptsuperscript𝜇430Υsubscript𝜎1superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE1𝜌1𝜌subscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE2𝜆1𝜆\mathcal{X}=\frac{2^{1/3}}{\mu^{4/3}_{0}\Upsilon}\left(\frac{\sigma_{1}\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(1)}}{\rho(1-\rho)}-\frac{\sigma_{2}\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(2)}}{\lambda(1-\lambda)}\right), (1.5)

and

𝒩=21/3μ04/3​Υ​(σ1​(1−2​ρ)​ξGOE(1)ρ​(1−ρ)−σ2​(1−2​λ)​ξGOE(2)λ​(1−λ)).𝒩superscript213subscriptsuperscript𝜇430Υsubscript𝜎112𝜌superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE1𝜌1𝜌subscript𝜎212𝜆superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE2𝜆1𝜆\mathcal{N}=\frac{2^{1/3}}{\mu^{4/3}_{0}\Upsilon}\left(\frac{\sigma_{1}(1-2\rho)\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(1)}}{\rho(1-\rho)}-\frac{\sigma_{2}(1-2\lambda)\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(2)}}{\lambda(1-\lambda)}\right). (1.6)

Here, ξGOE(1)superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE1\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(1)} and ξGOE(2)superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE2\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(2)} are two independent GOE Tracy-Widom distributed random variables [34], and the constants are given by

𝐯:=1−λ−ρ,μ0:=21−λ−ρ+2​λ​ρ,Υ:=1−2​λλ​(1−λ)−1−2​ρρ​(1−ρ),formulae-sequenceassign𝐯1𝜆𝜌formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝜇021𝜆𝜌2𝜆𝜌assignΥ12𝜆𝜆1𝜆12𝜌𝜌1𝜌\mathbf{v}:=1-\lambda-\rho,\quad\mu_{0}:=\frac{2}{1-\lambda-\rho+2\lambda\rho},\quad\Upsilon:=\frac{1-2\lambda}{\lambda(1-\lambda)}-\frac{1-2\rho}{\rho(1-\rho)}, (1.7)

and

σ1:=21/3(λ​(1−λ)​(1−λ−ρ+2​λ​ρ))1/3,σ2:=21/3(ρ​(1−ρ)​(1−λ−ρ+2​λ​ρ))1/3.formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝜎1superscript213superscript𝜆1𝜆1𝜆𝜌2𝜆𝜌13assignsubscript𝜎2superscript213superscript𝜌1𝜌1𝜆𝜌2𝜆𝜌13\sigma_{1}:=\frac{2^{1/3}}{\left(\lambda(1-\lambda)(1-\lambda-\rho+2\lambda\rho)\right)^{1/3}},\quad\sigma_{2}:=\frac{2^{1/3}}{\left(\rho(1-\rho)(1-\lambda-\rho+2\lambda\rho)\right)^{1/3}}. (1.8)

One aspect of Theorem 1.1 is the form of the limiting distribution. It is a linear combination of two independent random variables. This is directly related to the fact that the shock is the location where two characteristic lines meet. Secondly, the t1/3superscript𝑡13t^{1/3} scale is indirectly related with the fact that TASEP is in the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) universality class [24] in 1+1111+1 dimensions (see surveys and lecture notes [21, 7, 33, 4, 32, 16]). Finally the GOE Tracy-Widom distribution is due to fact that the regions from where the two characteristic lines starts are have fixed densities and they are non-random (such situations are called flat initial conditions for KPZ models [30, 14], see Proposition 3.1).

Further, Theorem 1.1 indeed shows that that the t1/2superscript𝑡12t^{1/2} fluctuation of Xtsubscript𝑋𝑡X_{t} (and the Gaussian distribution) observed with Bernoulli-Bernoulli initial condition strongly depends on the randomness of the initial condition. The reason is that the fluctuations generated by the dynamics (of KPZ type) are not visible as they are much smaller than the Gaussian fluctuations of the initial condition of the two regions which are strongly correlated with the shock. Finally, notice that when λ−ρ→0→𝜆𝜌0\lambda-\rho\to 0, the constant ΥΥ\Upsilon in (1.7) converges to 00. This is not surprising as a similar phenomenon has been observed for the random initial condition, λ−ρ→0→𝜆𝜌0\lambda-\rho\to 0 corresponds to look at the stationary initial condition, where the position of the second class particle has a non-trivial limiting distribution in the t2/3superscript𝑡23t^{2/3} scale [20, 31].

On the way to Theorem 1.1, we determine a technical result which, however, has its own interest. In Lemma 3.6 we find a Gaussian bound for the tail of the distribution of the starting point (or, exit point) of a geodesic in the stationary model of last passage percolation (defined in (3.41)) from a line to a point.

Method and outline

The result of the paper uses as first ingredient the asymptotic independence of the last passage times from two disjoint initial set of points of a last passage percolation (LPP) model [17], see Proposition 3.1, which is a consequence of slow-decorrelation [15, 8]. The trajectory of the second class particle is the same as the competition interface in LPP introduced by Ferrari and Pimentel in [13]. It is however not straightforward to extend the result on the competition interface of Ferrari and Nejjar, Theorem 2.1 of [18], to the position of the second class particle. The reason being that between the two observables there is a random time change and the second class particle moves with non-zero speed.

The next key ingredient in the proof is a tightness-type result on the two LPP problems, see Proposition 3.2 and Corollary 3.4. This extends to general densities the method of Pimentel [29], which extends the comparison with the stationary process by Cator and Pimentel [6], see Lemma 3.5. For its application one has to estimate the tail probabilities of the exit points, see Lemma 3.6 and Lemma 3.8. The latter as well as the limiting GOE Tracy-Widom distributions are taken from the recent universality result for flat initial condition by Ferrari and Occelli [19].

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we recall the connection between TASEP and LPP as well between second class particle and competition interface. We then collect asymptotic result on LPP which are used later. Section 3.2 contains the proof of Theorem 1.1. It is based of preliminary results on the control of LPP at different points, whose proof is presented after the one of the main theorem.

2 Some results on TASEP and LPP

Here we first recall the connection between TASEP and LPP, then between the second class particle and the competition interface, and finally we collect some known result about LPP.

2.1 Last passage percolation and connection with TASEP

We consider last passage percolation (LPP) on ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}. To define it, let ℒS,ℒE⊂ℤ2subscriptℒ𝑆subscriptℒ𝐸superscriptℤ2\mathcal{L}_{S},\mathcal{L}_{E}\subset\mathbb{Z}^{2}. Then the last passage percolation time from ℒSsubscriptℒ𝑆\mathcal{L}_{S} to ℒEsubscriptℒ𝐸\mathcal{L}_{E} is defined as

2.2 Competition interface and second class particles

These two clusters are separated through the competition interface ϕ=(ϕ0,ϕ1,ϕ2,…),italic-ϕsubscriptitalic-ϕ0subscriptitalic-ϕ1subscriptitalic-ϕ2…\phi=(\phi_{0},\phi_{1},\phi_{2},\ldots), defined by setting ϕ0=(0,0)subscriptitalic-ϕ000\phi_{0}=(0,0) and

ϕn+1={ϕn+(1,0)ifϕn+(1,1)∈Γ+∞,ϕn+(0,1)ifϕn+(1,1)∈Γ−∞,subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛1casessubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛10ifsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛11superscriptsubscriptΓotherwisesubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛01ifsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛11superscriptsubscriptΓotherwise\phi_{n+1}=\begin{cases}\phi_{n}+(1,0)\quad\mathrm{if}\quad\phi_{n}+(1,1)\in\Gamma_{+}^{\infty},\\ \phi_{n}+(0,1)\quad\mathrm{if}\quad\phi_{n}+(1,1)\in\Gamma_{-}^{\infty},\end{cases} (2.7)

We write ϕn=(In,Jn),n≥0,formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛subscript𝐼𝑛subscript𝐽𝑛𝑛0\phi_{n}=(I_{n},J_{n}),n\geq 0, by definition In+Jn=nsubscript𝐼𝑛subscript𝐽𝑛𝑛I_{n}+J_{n}=n. In our construction, we always have ϕ1=(1,0)subscriptitalic-ϕ110\phi_{1}=(1,0). Now, in [13] a coupling was introduced between the competition interface and the second class particle, see [12], Proposition 2.2, for the statement for general TASEP initial data. In the construction of [12], TASEP with a second class particle initially at the origin is seen to be equivalent to TASEP without a second class particle, but an extra site, and initially a hole at the origin and a particle at site 1. Associating to this initial data the sets (2.2), (2.5) and the competition interface, In−Jn−1subscript𝐼𝑛subscript𝐽𝑛1I_{n}-J_{n}-1 becomes the position of the second class particle after its (n−1)​th𝑛1th(n-1)\mathrm{th} step, i.e. by setting τn=Lℒ→ϕnsubscript𝜏𝑛subscript𝐿→ℒsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\tau_{n}=L_{\mathcal{L}\to\phi_{n}} and defining

(I​(t),J​(t))=ϕn,t∈[τn,τn+1)formulae-sequence𝐼𝑡𝐽𝑡subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑡subscript𝜏𝑛subscript𝜏𝑛1(I(t),J(t))=\phi_{n},\quad t\in[\tau_{n},\tau_{n+1}) (2.8)

the coupling of [12] makes that

(I​(t)−J​(t)−1)t≥0=(Xt)t≥0subscript𝐼𝑡𝐽𝑡1𝑡0subscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑡0(I(t)-J(t)-1)_{t\geq 0}=(X_{t})_{t\geq 0} (2.9)

(the shift by −11-1 is not present in [12], due to slightly different conventions).

2.3 Some asymptotic results for LPP

We consider i.i.d. weights {ωi,j}i,j∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝜔𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗ℤ\{\omega_{i,j}\}_{i,j\in\mathbb{Z}} with ωi,j∼Exp(1)similar-tosubscript𝜔𝑖𝑗Exp(1)\omega_{i,j}\sim\mbox{Exp(1)}, where Exp​(1)Exp1\mbox{Exp}(1) denotes the exponential distribution with intensity 111. The basic result about convergence of the point-to-point LPP time is the following.

Proposition 2.1 (Theorem 1.6 of [23]).

Let 0<η<∞0𝜂0<\eta<\infty. Then,

limN→∞ℙ​(L0→(⌊ηN⌋,⌊N⌋≤μp​p​N+s​ση​N1/3)=FGUE​(s)\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\left(L_{0\to(\lfloor\eta N\rfloor,\lfloor N\rfloor}\leq\mu_{pp}N+s\sigma_{\eta}N^{1/3}\right)=F_{\mathrm{GUE}}(s) (2.10)

where μp​p=(1+η)2subscript𝜇𝑝𝑝superscript1𝜂2\mu_{pp}=(1+\sqrt{\eta})^{2}, and ση=η−1/6​(1+η)4/3subscript𝜎𝜂superscript𝜂16superscript1𝜂43\sigma_{\eta}=\eta^{-1/6}(1+\sqrt{\eta})^{4/3}, and FGUEsubscript𝐹GUEF_{\mathrm{GUE}} is the GUE Tracy-Widom distribution function.

Further, we need the following upper/lower tail estimates for the distribution of L0→(η​N,N)subscript𝐿→0𝜂𝑁𝑁L_{0\to(\eta N,N)}. These estimates were collected in [17], based on results from [1, 2, 20].

Proposition 2.2 (Proposition 4.2 in [17]).

Let 0<η<∞0𝜂0<\eta<\infty. Then for any given n0>0subscript𝑛00n_{0}>0 and s0∈ℝsubscript𝑠0ℝs_{0}\in\mathbb{R}, there exists constants C,c>0𝐶𝑐0C,c>0 only dependent on N0,s0subscript𝑁0subscript𝑠0N_{0},s_{0} such that for all N≥N0𝑁subscript𝑁0N\geq N_{0} and s≥s0𝑠subscript𝑠0s\geq s_{0}, we have

ℙ​(L0→(⌊η​N⌋,⌊N⌋)>μp​p​N+s​N1/3)≤C​exp⁡(−c​s)ℙsubscript𝐿→0𝜂𝑁𝑁subscript𝜇𝑝𝑝𝑁𝑠superscript𝑁13𝐶𝑐𝑠\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(L_{0\to(\lfloor\eta N\rfloor,\lfloor N\rfloor)}>\mu_{pp}N+sN^{1/3}\right)\leq C\exp(-cs) (2.11)

where μp​p=(1+η)2subscript𝜇𝑝𝑝superscript1𝜂2\mu_{pp}=(1+\sqrt{\eta})^{2}.

Proposition 2.3 (Proposition 4.3 in [17]).

Let 0<η<∞0𝜂0<\eta<\infty and μp​p=(1+η)2subscript𝜇𝑝𝑝superscript1𝜂2\mu_{pp}=(1+\sqrt{\eta})^{2}. There exists positive constants s0,N0,C,csubscript𝑠0subscript𝑁0𝐶𝑐s_{0},N_{0},C,c such that the following holds

ℙ​(L0→(⌊η​N⌋,⌊N⌋)≤μp​p​N+s​N1/3)≤C​exp⁡(−c​|s|3/2)ℙsubscript𝐿→0𝜂𝑁𝑁subscript𝜇𝑝𝑝𝑁𝑠superscript𝑁13𝐶𝑐superscript𝑠32\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(L_{0\to(\lfloor\eta N\rfloor,\lfloor N\rfloor)}\leq\mu_{pp}N+sN^{1/3}\right)\leq C\exp(-c|s|^{3/2}) (2.12)

for all s≤−s0,N≥N0formulae-sequence𝑠subscript𝑠0𝑁subscript𝑁0s\leq-s_{0},N\geq N_{0}.

Recall our initial data

xn​(0)subscript𝑥𝑛0\displaystyle x_{n}(0) =−⌊λ−1​n⌋absentsuperscript𝜆1𝑛\displaystyle=-\left\lfloor\lambda^{-1}n\right\rfloor when ​n>0,when 𝑛0\displaystyle\quad\text{when }n>0, (2.13)
xn​(0)subscript𝑥𝑛0\displaystyle x_{n}(0) =−⌊ρ−1​n⌋absentsuperscript𝜌1𝑛\displaystyle=-\left\lfloor\rho^{-1}n\right\rfloor when ​n≤0,when 𝑛0\displaystyle\quad\text{when }n\leq 0,

where 0<λ<ρ<10𝜆𝜌10<\lambda<\rho<1. This creates a shock into the system. We consider the following anti-diagonal lines

ℒλ:={(⌊λ−1λ​x⌋,x):x∈ℤ≥0},ℒρ:={(⌊ρ−1ρ​x⌋,x):x∈ℤ<0}.formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptℒ𝜆conditional-set𝜆1𝜆𝑥𝑥𝑥subscriptℤabsent0assignsubscriptℒ𝜌conditional-set𝜌1𝜌𝑥𝑥𝑥subscriptℤabsent0\displaystyle{\cal L}_{\lambda}:=\left\{\left(\big{\lfloor}\tfrac{\lambda-1}{\lambda}x\big{\rfloor},x\right):x\in\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}\right\},\quad{\cal L}_{\rho}:=\left\{\left(\big{\lfloor}\tfrac{\rho-1}{\rho}x\big{\rfloor},x\right):x\in\mathbb{Z}_{<0}\right\}. (2.14)

The next result consists in the limiting law from ℒρsubscriptℒ𝜌{\cal L}_{\rho} and ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆{\cal L}_{\lambda}.

Lemma 2.4.

limN→∞ℙ​(Lℒλ→((1+γ)​N,(1−γ)​N)−μ0​NN1/3≤s)=FGOE​(22/3​sσ1),subscript→𝑁ℙsubscript𝐿→subscriptℒ𝜆1𝛾𝑁1𝛾𝑁subscript𝜇0𝑁superscript𝑁13𝑠subscript𝐹GOEsuperscript223𝑠subscript𝜎1\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\left(\frac{L_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}\to((1+\gamma)N,(1-\gamma)N)}-\mu_{0}N}{N^{1/3}}\leq s\right)=F_{\mathrm{GOE}}\left(\frac{2^{2/3}s}{\sigma_{1}}\right), (2.16)

(2.17)
Proof.

Let us define ℒρ∞={(⌊(ρ−1)​x/ρ⌋,x),x∈ℤ}superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌𝜌1𝑥𝜌𝑥𝑥ℤ{\cal L}_{\rho}^{\infty}=\{(\lfloor(\rho-1)x/\rho\rfloor,x),x\in\mathbb{Z}\} the two-sided extension of ℒρsubscriptℒ𝜌{\cal L}_{\rho}. Let Q𝑄Q the projection of

P=((1+γ)​N,(1−γ)​N)𝑃1𝛾𝑁1𝛾𝑁P=((1+\gamma)N,(1-\gamma)N) (2.18)

along the (1,1)11(1,1) direction onto ℒρ∞superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌{\cal L}_{\rho}^{\infty}, as illustrated in Figure 1.

It is given by

Q=(2​(1−ρ)​γ​N,−2​γ​ρ​N).𝑄21𝜌𝛾𝑁2𝛾𝜌𝑁Q=(2(1-\rho)\gamma N,-2\gamma\rho N). (2.19)

Thus

limN→∞ℙ​(Lℒρ→((1+γ)​N,(1−γ)​N)−μ0​NN1/3≤s)=limN~→∞ℙ​(Lℒ~ρ→(N~,N~)−a0​N~a1​N~1/3≤sσ1)subscript→𝑁ℙsubscript𝐿→subscriptℒ𝜌1𝛾𝑁1𝛾𝑁subscript𝜇0𝑁superscript𝑁13𝑠subscript→~𝑁ℙsubscript𝐿→subscript~ℒ𝜌~𝑁~𝑁subscript𝑎0~𝑁subscript𝑎1superscript~𝑁13𝑠subscript𝜎1\lim_{N\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\left(\frac{L_{{\cal L}_{\rho}\to((1+\gamma)N,(1-\gamma)N)}-\mu_{0}N}{N^{1/3}}\leq s\right)=\lim_{\tilde{N}\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\left(\frac{L_{\widetilde{\cal L}_{\rho}\to(\tilde{N},\tilde{N})}-a_{0}\tilde{N}}{a_{1}\tilde{N}^{1/3}}\leq\frac{s}{\sigma_{1}}\right) (2.20)

with a0=1/(ρ​(1−ρ))subscript𝑎01𝜌1𝜌a_{0}=1/(\rho(1-\rho)) and a1=1/(ρ​(1−ρ))2/3subscript𝑎11superscript𝜌1𝜌23a_{1}=1/(\rho(1-\rho))^{2/3}. In Theorem 2.1 of [19] it is proven that

Due to the condition ρ>λ𝜌𝜆\rho>\lambda, the starting point of the line ℒ~ρsubscript~ℒ𝜌\widetilde{\cal L}_{\rho} is of order N~~𝑁\tilde{N} to the left of A~~𝐴\widetilde{A}. Thus one has

limN~→∞ℙ​(Lℒ~ρ→(N~,N~)−a0​N~a1​N~1/3≤sσ1)=limN~→∞ℙ​(Lℒρ∞→(N~,N~)−a0​N~a1​N~1/3≤sσ1).subscript→~𝑁ℙsubscript𝐿→subscript~ℒ𝜌~𝑁~𝑁subscript𝑎0~𝑁subscript𝑎1superscript~𝑁13𝑠subscript𝜎1subscript→~𝑁ℙsubscript𝐿→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜌~𝑁~𝑁subscript𝑎0~𝑁subscript𝑎1superscript~𝑁13𝑠subscript𝜎1\lim_{\tilde{N}\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\left(\frac{L_{\widetilde{\cal L}_{\rho}\to(\tilde{N},\tilde{N})}-a_{0}\tilde{N}}{a_{1}\tilde{N}^{1/3}}\leq\frac{s}{\sigma_{1}}\right)=\lim_{\tilde{N}\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\left(\frac{L_{{\cal L}_{\rho}^{\infty}\to(\tilde{N},\tilde{N})}-a_{0}\tilde{N}}{a_{1}\tilde{N}^{1/3}}\leq\frac{s}{\sigma_{1}}\right). (2.22)

Combining (2.20)-(2.22) we get (2.16). The statement (2.17) is proven analogously. ∎

By maximizing the point-to-point law of large numbers, one gets that the maximizers from ℒρsubscriptℒ𝜌{\cal L}_{\rho} to P𝑃P (defined in (2.18)) starts, on the 𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(N) scale, from

Aρ=((ρ−1)/ρ,1)​ξρ​N,ξρ=−2​(ρ−λ)​ρ1−λ−ρ+2​λ​ρ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐴𝜌𝜌1𝜌1subscript𝜉𝜌𝑁subscript𝜉𝜌2𝜌𝜆𝜌1𝜆𝜌2𝜆𝜌A_{\rho}=((\rho-1)/\rho,1)\xi_{\rho}N,\quad\xi_{\rho}=\frac{-2(\rho-\lambda)\rho}{1-\lambda-\rho+2\lambda\rho}. (2.23)

The straight line passing from Aρsubscript𝐴𝜌A_{\rho} to P𝑃P (defined in (2.18)) is the characteristic and it has direction given by ((1−ρ)2,ρ2)superscript1𝜌2superscript𝜌2((1-\rho)^{2},\rho^{2}). Similarly, the maximizers from ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆{\cal L}_{\lambda} to P𝑃P starts, on the 𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(N) scale, from

Aλ=((λ−1)/λ,1)​ξλ​N,ξλ=2​(ρ−λ)​λ1−λ−ρ+2​λ​ρ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐴𝜆𝜆1𝜆1subscript𝜉𝜆𝑁subscript𝜉𝜆2𝜌𝜆𝜆1𝜆𝜌2𝜆𝜌A_{\lambda}=((\lambda-1)/\lambda,1)\xi_{\lambda}N,\quad\xi_{\lambda}=\frac{2(\rho-\lambda)\lambda}{1-\lambda-\rho+2\lambda\rho}. (2.24)

Slow decorrelation [15, 8] says that the fluctuations from ℒρsubscriptℒ𝜌{\cal L}_{\rho} and ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆{\cal L}_{\lambda} to the end-point are almost the same as the ones from these lines to a point of the characteristic line at a o​(N)𝑜𝑁o(N) distance to the end-point. Therefore, for any 0<ν<10𝜈10<\nu<1, we define the points on the characteristics

Eρsubscript𝐸𝜌\displaystyle E_{\rho} =\displaystyle= ((1+γ)​N−(1−ρ)2​Nν,(1−γ)​N−ρ2​Nν),1𝛾𝑁superscript1𝜌2superscript𝑁𝜈1𝛾𝑁superscript𝜌2superscript𝑁𝜈\displaystyle((1+\gamma)N-(1-\rho)^{2}N^{\nu},(1-\gamma)N-\rho^{2}N^{\nu}), (2.25)
Eλsubscript𝐸𝜆\displaystyle E_{\lambda} =\displaystyle= ((1+γ)​N−(1−λ)2​Nν,(1−γ)​N−λ2​Nν),1𝛾𝑁superscript1𝜆2superscript𝑁𝜈1𝛾𝑁superscript𝜆2superscript𝑁𝜈\displaystyle((1+\gamma)N-(1-\lambda)^{2}N^{\nu},(1-\gamma)N-\lambda^{2}N^{\nu}), (2.26)

see Figure 2.

Lemma 2.5.

There exists some μ~1​(γ)subscript~𝜇1𝛾\tilde{\mu}_{1}(\gamma) and μ~2​(γ)subscript~𝜇2𝛾\tilde{\mu}_{2}(\gamma) such that

Proof.

(2.27) follows from Proposition 2.1, while (2.28) are obtained as in Lemma 2.4. ∎

Lemma 2.6.

Fix any 2/3<β<123𝛽12/3<\beta<1. For η∈𝒥β,N:=[0,1−Nβ−1]𝜂subscript𝒥𝛽𝑁assign01superscript𝑁𝛽1\eta\in\mathcal{J}_{\beta,N}:=[0,1-N^{\beta-1}] define the points Dη=(⌊η​(1+γ)​N⌋,⌊η​(1−γ)​N⌋)subscript𝐷𝜂𝜂1𝛾𝑁𝜂1𝛾𝑁D_{\eta}=(\lfloor\eta(1+\gamma)N\rfloor,\lfloor\eta(1-\gamma)N\rfloor). Then

3 Proof of the main theorem

In Section 3.1 we provide some results on the limiting LPP problems as well as tightness-type results. The proofs are mostly postponed to Section 3.3. These results are then employed to prove the main result, Theorem 1.1 in Section 3.2.

3.1 Preliminary results

The very first result of this section corresponds to the scaling limit of the last passage times from two half lines ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆\cal{L}_{\lambda} and ℒρsubscriptℒ𝜌\cal{L}_{\rho} to the points (on the line x+y=2​N𝑥𝑦2𝑁x+y=2N) lying in a neighborhood of ((1+γ)​N,(1−γ)​N)1𝛾𝑁1𝛾𝑁((1+\gamma)N,(1-\gamma)N) (see (2.15) for γ𝛾\gamma). Before stating the result, we introduce some notations. Recall that P=((1+γ)​N,(1−γ)​N)𝑃1𝛾𝑁1𝛾𝑁P=((1+\gamma)N,(1-\gamma)N). Any point on the line x+y=2​N𝑥𝑦2𝑁x+y=2N can be written as ((1+γ)​N+U,(1−γ)​N−U)1𝛾𝑁𝑈1𝛾𝑁𝑈((1+\gamma)N+U,(1-\gamma)N-U) for some U∈ℝ𝑈ℝU\in\mathbb{R}. For convenience, we denote

P​(U):=((1+γ)​N+U,(1−γ)​N−U),assign𝑃𝑈1𝛾𝑁𝑈1𝛾𝑁𝑈P(U):=\left((1+\gamma)N+U,(1-\gamma)N-U\right), (3.1)

so that P=P​(0)𝑃𝑃0P=P(0), see Figure 3 for an illustration.

We further define the “spatial” rescaled process

Proposition 3.1.

Recall the definition of μ,σ1𝜇subscript𝜎1\mu,\sigma_{1} and σ2subscript𝜎2\sigma_{2} from Theorem 1.1. Then, for any fixed u∈ℝ𝑢ℝu\in\mathbb{R}, we have

limN→∞ℙ​(LNresc,λ​(u)≤s)subscript→𝑁ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁𝑢𝑠\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\big{(}L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u)\leq s\big{)} =FGOE​(22/3​sσ1),absentsubscript𝐹GOEsuperscript223𝑠subscript𝜎1\displaystyle=F_{\mathrm{GOE}}\left(\frac{2^{2/3}s}{\sigma_{1}}\right), (3.4)

Proof.

The limiting formulas (3.4) are obtained by replacing γ→γ+u​N−2/3→𝛾𝛾𝑢superscript𝑁23\gamma\to\gamma+uN^{-2/3} in the derivation of Lemma 2.4. Similarly, Lemma 2.5 holds also with γ→γ+u​N−2/3→𝛾𝛾𝑢superscript𝑁23\gamma\to\gamma+uN^{-2/3}, so that the end-point of the LPP problem is P​(u​N1/3)=((1+γ)​N+u​N1/3,(1−γ)​N−u​N1/3)𝑃𝑢superscript𝑁131𝛾𝑁𝑢superscript𝑁131𝛾𝑁𝑢superscript𝑁13P(uN^{1/3})=\left((1+\gamma)N+uN^{1/3},(1-\gamma)N-uN^{1/3}\right). Concerning the asymptotic independence, it can be obtained as a consequence of the general Theorem 2.1 in [17], which holds under three Assumptions given in [17]. Now (3.4) verifies Assumption 1 of [17]. Lemma 2.5 verifies Assumption 2 of [17] (upon replacing P𝑃P by P​(u​N1/3)𝑃𝑢superscript𝑁13P(uN^{1/3})), which are the hypothesis of the slow-decorrelation theorem, see Theorem 2.1 of [8]. This theorem implies that difference of LNresc,λ​(u)subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁𝑢L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u) (or, LNresc,ρ​(u)subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜌𝑁𝑢L^{{\rm resc},\rho}_{N}(u)) and random variables defined in (2.28) (of course making the replacement γ→γ+u​N−2/3→𝛾𝛾𝑢superscript𝑁23\gamma\to\gamma+uN^{-2/3}) goes to 00 in probability, as N→∞→𝑁N\to\infty. Finally, Lemma 2.6 verifies Assumption 3 of [17], which says that that the maximizers to Eλsubscript𝐸𝜆E_{\lambda} and Eρsubscript𝐸𝜌E_{\rho} stay in two separate sets of independent random variables with probability 111 as N→∞→𝑁N\to\infty. This finishes the proof. ∎

By KPZ scaling theory, one expects that the processes u↦LNresc,λ​(u​N1/3)maps-to𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁𝑢superscript𝑁13u\mapsto L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(uN^{1/3}) (resp, u↦LNresc,ρ​(u​N1/3)maps-to𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜌𝑁𝑢superscript𝑁13u\mapsto L^{{\rm resc},\rho}_{N}(uN^{1/3})) converges to an Airy1 process in u𝑢u (see [19] for a proof of it). This means that if we look at the processes u↦LNresc,λ​(u)maps-to𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁𝑢u\mapsto L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u) (or, LNresc,λ​(u)subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁𝑢L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u)), then it will converges to a process with constant value in the N→∞→𝑁N\to\infty limit. The reason why we consider here the latter scaling is that the shock, which is the observable that we want to analyze, has width of order N1/3superscript𝑁13N^{1/3} only. For proving Theorem 1.1 we will need to make this observation precise.

Proposition 3.2.

Fix any C>0𝐶0C>0. Then, for any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 , we have

limN→∞ℙ(sup|u|,|v|≤C|LNresc,λ(u)−LNresc,λ(v)|)>ε)=0,\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\bigg{(}\sup_{|u|,|v|\leq C}|L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u)-L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(v)|)>\varepsilon\bigg{)}=0, (3.5)
limN→∞ℙ(sup|u|,|v|≤C|LNresc,ρ(u)−LNresc,ρ(v)|)>ε)=0.\displaystyle\lim_{N\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\bigg{(}\sup_{|u|,|v|\leq C}|L^{{\rm resc},\rho}_{N}(u)-L^{{\rm resc},\rho}_{N}(v)|)>\varepsilon\bigg{)}=0. (3.6)

At time t𝑡t, the second class particle will correspond to a point on the competition interface be at a distance O​(N1/3)𝑂superscript𝑁13O(N^{1/3}) around the position P𝑃P, but with a N𝑁N not being fixed, rather also fluctuating of order t1/3superscript𝑡13t^{1/3} around a macroscopic value. For that reason we will have to consider increments of the process in a N1/3superscript𝑁13N^{1/3} neighborhood of P𝑃P in any directions. Thus let us extend the definition of P𝑃P as follow

and we use the notation

By Proposition 3.1, as N→∞→𝑁N\to\infty, χλ→σ1​2−2/3​ξGOE(1)→subscript𝜒𝜆subscript𝜎1superscript223superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE1\chi_{\lambda}\to\sigma_{1}2^{-2/3}\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(1)} and χρ→σ2​2−2/3​ξGOE(2)→subscript𝜒𝜌subscript𝜎2superscript223superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE2\chi_{\rho}\to\sigma_{2}2^{-2/3}\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(2)}, with ξGOE(i)superscriptsubscript𝜉GOE𝑖\xi_{\rm GOE}^{(i)}, i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2, being GOE Tracy-Widom distributed random variables [34] and asymptotically independent. This ends the proof of the main theorem.

3.3 Proofs of the preliminary results

First we deal with Proposition 3.2. We prove the result only in the case of ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆{\cal L}_{\lambda}, the case for ℒρsubscriptℒ𝜌{\cal L}_{\rho} is proven in the same way. The key ingredient is the coupling between the last passage percolation with two different initial profiles as in Lemma 2.1 of [29], one of which being stationary.

3.3.1 Comparison with stationary LPP

Recall that P=((1+γ)​N,(1−γ)​N)𝑃1𝛾𝑁1𝛾𝑁P=\left((1+\gamma)N,(1-\gamma)N\right). As already discussed

argmaxk≥0⁡{L(λ−1​(λ−1)​k,k)→P}subscriptargmax𝑘0subscript𝐿→superscript𝜆1𝜆1𝑘𝑘𝑃\operatorname{argmax}_{k\geq 0}\left\{L_{\left(\lambda^{-1}(\lambda-1)k,k\right)\to P}\right\} (3.34)

lies in the neighborhood of the point ξλsubscript𝜉𝜆\xi_{\lambda} defined in (2.24).

Using Lemma 4.2 of [3] one can define a stationary model where the starting line of the LPP is any right/down path, obtained by adding appropriate random weights to the points on the line. Let us define it for

One can bound ℙ​(ΩλN​[−C,C]≥ϵ)ℙsubscriptsuperscriptΩ𝑁𝜆𝐶𝐶italic-ϵ\mathbb{P}(\Omega^{N}_{\lambda}[-C,C]\geq\epsilon) by the sum of ℙ​((GN​(r))c)ℙsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑁𝑟𝑐\mathbb{P}((G_{N}(r))^{c}) and ℙ​(GN​(r)∩{ΩλN​[−C,C]≥ϵ})ℙsubscript𝐺𝑁𝑟subscriptsuperscriptΩ𝑁𝜆𝐶𝐶italic-ϵ\mathbb{P}(G_{N}(r)\cap\{\Omega^{N}_{\lambda}[-C,C]\geq\epsilon\}). First lemma corresponds to a coupling between the last passage percolation with boundary conditions ω𝜔\omega and the ones without them. This is an extension of Lemma 2.1 of [29] to the case of general ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho.

Lemma 3.5.

Fix some 0<x1<x20subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥20<x_{1}<x_{2}. Now, whenever Zstat,ϱ​(x1)≤Zλ​(x2)superscript𝑍statitalic-ϱsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑍𝜆subscript𝑥2Z^{{\rm stat},\varrho}(x_{1})\leq Z_{\lambda}(x_{2}), then we get

Lℒλ→P​(x2)−Lℒλ→P​(x1)≤Lℒλ∞→P​(x2)stat,ϱ−Lℒλ∞→P​(x1)stat,ϱ.subscript𝐿→subscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2subscript𝐿→subscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1subscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱ→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2subscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱ→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1\displaystyle L_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{2})}-L_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{1})}\leq L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(x_{2})}-L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(x_{1})}. (3.49)

In contrast, when Zλ​(x1)≤Zstat,ϱ​(x2)subscript𝑍𝜆subscript𝑥1superscript𝑍statitalic-ϱsubscript𝑥2Z_{\lambda}(x_{1})\leq Z^{{\rm stat},\varrho}(x_{2}) holds, then we have

Lℒλ∞→P​(x2)stat,ϱ−Lℒλ∞→P​(x1)stat,ϱ≤Lℒλ→P​(x2)−Lℒλ→P​(x1).subscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱ→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2subscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱ→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1subscript𝐿→subscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2subscript𝐿→subscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1\displaystyle L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(x_{2})}-L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(x_{1})}\leq L_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{2})}-L_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{1})}. (3.50)
Proof.

One can find similar result in Lemma 1 of [6] for the exit point in Hammerseley process. Furthermore, [29] it has been generalized in the case of line to point last passage percolation with any two initial profiles along the anti-diagonal. Our proof closely follows the arguments of Lemma 2.1 of [29]. We prove in detail only (3.49) since the proof of (3.50) is similar.

We denote z2=Zλ​(x2)subscript𝑧2subscript𝑍𝜆subscript𝑥2z_{2}=Z_{\lambda}(x_{2}) and z1=Zstat,ϱ​(x1)subscript𝑧1superscript𝑍statitalic-ϱsubscript𝑥1z_{1}=Z^{{\rm stat},\varrho}(x_{1}), see Figure 4 for an illustration.

Lℒλ∞→P​(x1)stat,ϱsubscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱ→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1\displaystyle L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(x_{1})} =ωϱ​(z1)+Lz1→𝐜λ+L𝐜λ→P​(x1),absentsuperscript𝜔italic-ϱsubscript𝑧1subscript𝐿→subscript𝑧1subscript𝐜𝜆subscript𝐿→subscript𝐜𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1\displaystyle=\omega^{\varrho}(z_{1})+L_{z_{1}\to\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}}+L_{\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{1})}, (3.51)
Lℒλ→P​(x2)subscript𝐿→subscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2\displaystyle L_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{2})} =Lz2→𝐜λ+L𝐜λ→P​(x2),absentsubscript𝐿→subscript𝑧2subscript𝐜𝜆subscript𝐿→subscript𝐜𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2\displaystyle=L_{z_{2}\to\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}}+L_{\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{2})}, (3.52)

and, by subadditivity of the last passage time, we have

Lℒλ∞→P​(x2)stat,ϱsubscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱ→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2\displaystyle L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(x_{2})} ≥ωϱ​(z1)+Lz1→𝐜λ+L𝐜λ→P​(x2),absentsuperscript𝜔italic-ϱsubscript𝑧1subscript𝐿→subscript𝑧1subscript𝐜𝜆subscript𝐿→subscript𝐜𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2\displaystyle\geq\omega^{\varrho}(z_{1})+L_{z_{1}\to\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}}+L_{\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{2})}, (3.53)
Lℒλ→P​(x1)subscript𝐿→subscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1\displaystyle L_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{1})} ≥Lz2→𝐜λ+L𝐜λ→P​(x1).absentsubscript𝐿→subscript𝑧2subscript𝐜𝜆subscript𝐿→subscript𝐜𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1\displaystyle\geq L_{z_{2}\to\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}}+L_{\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{1})}. (3.54)

Lℒλ∞→P​(x2)stat,ϱ−Lℒλ∞→P​(x1)stat,ϱ≥L𝐜λ→P​(x1)−L𝐜λ→P​(x2).subscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱ→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2subscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱ→superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1subscript𝐿→subscript𝐜𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥1subscript𝐿→subscript𝐜𝜆𝑃subscript𝑥2\displaystyle L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(x_{2})}-L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(x_{1})}\geq L_{\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{1})}-L_{\mathbf{c}_{\lambda}\to P(x_{2})}. (3.49) follows by combining (3.55) and (3.56). ∎

3.3.2 Bounds on exit points probability

In what follows, we state a result for the exit point Zstat,ϱsuperscript𝑍statitalic-ϱZ^{{\rm stat},\varrho} of the stationary last passage percolation. A weaker bound with the restriction on ϱ∈[1/4,3/4]italic-ϱ1434\varrho\in[1/4,3/4] can be found in Lemma 2.2 of [29].

Lemma 3.6.

Fix any ϱ∈(0,1)italic-ϱ01\varrho\in(0,1) and c∈ℝ>0𝑐subscriptℝabsent0c\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}. Consider the stationary last passage percolation model Lℒλ∞stat,ϱsubscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱsubscriptsuperscriptℒ𝜆L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{\mathcal{L}^{\infty}_{\lambda}}. Denote the exit point of the last passage path from ℒλ∞subscriptsuperscriptℒ𝜆\mathcal{L}^{\infty}_{\lambda} to Pϱ​(x):=((1−ϱ)2​N+x,ϱ2​N−x)assignsuperscript𝑃italic-ϱ𝑥superscript1italic-ϱ2𝑁𝑥superscriptitalic-ϱ2𝑁𝑥P^{\varrho}(x):=((1-\varrho)^{2}N+x,\varrho^{2}N-x) by Z~stat,ϱ​(x)superscript~𝑍statitalic-ϱ𝑥\widetilde{Z}^{{\rm stat},\varrho}(x). Then, there exists M0=M0​(c,λ,ϱ)subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀0𝑐𝜆italic-ϱM_{0}=M_{0}(c,\lambda,\varrho) such that for all M≥M0𝑀subscript𝑀0M\geq M_{0}, we have

ℙ​(|Z~stat,ϱ​(c​N1/3)|≥M​N2/3)≤C1​e−C2​M2,ℙsuperscript~𝑍statitalic-ϱ𝑐superscript𝑁13𝑀superscript𝑁23subscript𝐶1superscript𝑒subscript𝐶2superscript𝑀2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\left|\widetilde{Z}^{{\rm stat},\varrho}(cN^{1/3})\right|\geq MN^{2/3}\right)\leq C_{1}e^{-C_{2}M^{2}}, (3.57)

uniformly for all large N𝑁N where C1:=C1​(λ,ϱ)assignsubscript𝐶1subscript𝐶1𝜆italic-ϱC_{1}:=C_{1}(\lambda,\varrho) and C2:=C2​(λ,ϱ)assignsubscript𝐶2subscript𝐶2𝜆italic-ϱC_{2}:=C_{2}(\lambda,\varrho) are two constants.

Proof.

We only show the bound on the upper tail. Proof of the lower tail follows by the same arguments. For the proof we need to divide the maximizer on several pieces. For that purpose, in this proof we denote by

La​(x):=maxk≥a⁡{L(λ−1​(λ−1)​k,k)→Pϱ​(x)+ωϱ​(k)}.assignsubscript𝐿𝑎𝑥subscript𝑘𝑎subscript𝐿→superscript𝜆1𝜆1𝑘𝑘superscript𝑃italic-ϱ𝑥superscript𝜔italic-ϱ𝑘L_{a}(x):=\max_{k\geq a}\{L_{(\lambda^{-1}(\lambda-1)k,k)\to P^{\varrho}(x)}+\omega^{\varrho}(k)\}. (3.58)

First notice that

ℙ​(ωϱ​(M​N2/3)≥s~)ℙsuperscript𝜔italic-ϱ𝑀superscript𝑁23~𝑠\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\omega^{\varrho}(MN^{2/3})\geq\tilde{s}\right) =ℙ​(∑i=1M​N2/3q~i+∑j=1λ−1​(1−λ)​M​N2/3p~j≥s^)absentℙsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀superscript𝑁23subscript~𝑞𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1superscript𝜆11𝜆𝑀superscript𝑁23subscript~𝑝𝑗^𝑠\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}\Bigg{(}\sum_{i=1}^{MN^{2/3}}\tilde{q}_{i}+\sum_{j=1}^{\lambda^{-1}(1-\lambda)MN^{2/3}}\tilde{p}_{j}\geq\hat{s}\Bigg{)} (3.64)

It remains to bound the second term in (3.63). After shifting the half-line to start at the origin, RM​N2/3​(c​N1/3)subscript𝑅𝑀superscript𝑁23𝑐superscript𝑁13R_{MN^{2/3}}(cN^{1/3}) becomes the LPP from (0,0)00(0,0) to (γ2n,n)=(1−ϱ)2N+cN1/3+λ−1(1−λ)MN2/3,ϱ2N−cN1/3−MN2/3)(\gamma^{2}n,n)=(1-\varrho)^{2}N+cN^{1/3}+\lambda^{-1}(1-\lambda)MN^{2/3},\varrho^{2}N-cN^{1/3}-MN^{2/3}) with one-sided vertical boundary sources with parameter ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho. This LPP was studied in [1] in terms of sample covariance matrices (see their Section 6 for the connection to LPP). In their proof they obtained exponential bounds used then to show the convergence to the limiting law. These bounds implies exponential bounds for the right tail of the distribution. An explicit statement in the LPP language of this bound can be found in Lemma 3.3 of [19]. In our case it corresponds to have a κ=(λ−2​λ​ϱ+ϱ2)​M2​λ​ϱ​(1−ϱ)𝜅𝜆2𝜆italic-ϱsuperscriptitalic-ϱ2𝑀2𝜆italic-ϱ1italic-ϱ\kappa=\frac{(\lambda-2\lambda\varrho+\varrho^{2})M}{2\lambda\varrho(1-\varrho)}. Using (3.8) and the first bound of Lemma 3.3 of [19] with the choice a=14​(1−ϱ)2/3+O​(1/M2)𝑎14superscript1italic-ϱ23𝑂1superscript𝑀2a=\frac{1}{4(1-\varrho)^{2/3}}+O(1/M^{2}) (to match with s¯¯𝑠\bar{s}), we get uniformly for large N𝑁N,

for all M≥M0𝑀subscript𝑀0M\geq M_{0}, M0subscript𝑀0M_{0} a constant and C,c𝐶𝑐C,c some M𝑀M-independent constants. This ends the proof of (3.57). ∎

Below, we note down a simple corollary of Lemma 3.6.

Corollary 3.7.

Recall the definition of P​(⋅)𝑃⋅P(\cdot) given in (3.1). Consider the last passage percolation model Lℒλ∞stat,ϱsubscriptsuperscript𝐿statitalic-ϱsubscriptsuperscriptℒ𝜆L^{{\rm stat},\varrho}_{{\cal L}^{\infty}_{\lambda}} for ϱ=λ±italic-ϱsubscript𝜆plus-or-minus\varrho=\lambda_{\pm}. Let ξλ±subscriptsuperscript𝜉plus-or-minus𝜆\xi^{\pm}_{\lambda} be such that the line joining the points QN​(ξλ±):=(λ−1​(λ−1)​ξλ±​N,ξλ±​N)assignsubscript𝑄𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝜉plus-or-minus𝜆superscript𝜆1𝜆1subscriptsuperscript𝜉plus-or-minus𝜆𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝜉plus-or-minus𝜆𝑁Q_{N}(\xi^{\pm}_{\lambda}):=(\lambda^{-1}(\lambda-1)\xi^{\pm}_{\lambda}N,\xi^{\pm}_{\lambda}N) and P​(C​N1/3)𝑃𝐶superscript𝑁13P(CN^{1/3}) has direction ((1−λ±)2,(λ±)2)superscript1subscript𝜆plus-or-minus2superscriptsubscript𝜆plus-or-minus2((1-\lambda_{\pm})^{2},(\lambda_{\pm})^{2}). Then, there exists M0=M0​(λ)subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀0𝜆M_{0}=M_{0}(\lambda), K1=K1​(λ)subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾1𝜆K_{1}=K_{1}(\lambda) and K2=K2​(λ)subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾2𝜆K_{2}=K_{2}(\lambda) such that for all M≥M0𝑀subscript𝑀0M\geq M_{0}, the followings hold uniformly for all large N𝑁N

ℙ​(Zstat,λ+​(C​N1/3)−ξλ+​N<−M​N2/3)≤K1​exp⁡(−K2​M2),ℙsuperscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝜆𝑁𝑀superscript𝑁23subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2superscript𝑀2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{+}}(CN^{1/3})-\xi^{+}_{\lambda}N<-MN^{2/3}\right)\leq K_{1}\exp(-K_{2}M^{2}), (3.67)
ℙ​(Zstat,λ−​(C​N1/3)−ξλ−​N>M​N2/3)≤K1​exp⁡(−K2​M2).ℙsuperscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝜆𝑁𝑀superscript𝑁23subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2superscript𝑀2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{-}}(CN^{1/3})-\xi^{-}_{\lambda}N>MN^{2/3}\right)\leq K_{1}\exp(-K_{2}M^{2}). (3.68)
Proof.

To see this, we first translate X𝑋X-axis and Y𝑌Y-axis linearly so that the origin is moved to the points QN​(ξλ±)subscript𝑄𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝜉plus-or-minus𝜆Q_{N}(\xi^{\pm}_{\lambda}). ℙ​(Zstat,λ+​(C​N1/3)−ξλ+​N<−M​N2/3)=ℙ​(Z~stat,λ+<−M​N2/3),ℙsuperscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝜆𝑁𝑀superscript𝑁23ℙsuperscript~𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝑀superscript𝑁23\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{+}}(CN^{1/3})-\xi^{+}_{\lambda}N<-MN^{2/3}\right)=\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{Z}^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{+}}<-MN^{2/3}), (3.69)
ℙ​(Zstat,λ−​(C​N1/3)−ξλ−​N>M​N2/3)=ℙ​(Z~stat,λ−>M​N2/3).ℙsuperscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscriptsuperscript𝜉𝜆𝑁𝑀superscript𝑁23ℙsuperscript~𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝑀superscript𝑁23\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{-}}(CN^{1/3})-\xi^{-}_{\lambda}N>MN^{2/3}\right)=\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{Z}^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{-}}>MN^{2/3}).

Further, we have P~±​(C​N1/3)=t​((1−λ±)2​N,(λ±)2​N)subscript~𝑃plus-or-minus𝐶superscript𝑁13𝑡superscript1subscript𝜆plus-or-minus2𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜆plus-or-minus2𝑁\widetilde{P}_{\pm}(CN^{1/3})=t((1-\lambda_{\pm})^{2}N,(\lambda_{\pm})^{2}N) for some constant t>0𝑡0t>0.

From Lemma 3.6 applied for ϱ=λ±italic-ϱsubscript𝜆plus-or-minus\varrho=\lambda_{\pm}, there exists M0=M0​(λ)subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀0𝜆M_{0}=M_{0}(\lambda), K1=K1​(λ)subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾1𝜆K_{1}=K_{1}(\lambda) and K2=K2​(λ)subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾2𝜆K_{2}=K_{2}(\lambda) such that for all M≥M0𝑀subscript𝑀0M\geq M_{0}, we have

ℙ​(|Z~stat,λ±|>M​N2/3)≤K1​e−K2​M2,ℙsuperscript~𝑍statsubscript𝜆plus-or-minus𝑀superscript𝑁23subscript𝐾1superscript𝑒subscript𝐾2superscript𝑀2\mathbb{P}\left(|\widetilde{Z}^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{\pm}}|>MN^{2/3}\right)\leq K_{1}e^{-K_{2}M^{2}}, (3.70)

for all large N𝑁N. Since the probabilities in (3.69) are bounded by the ones in (3.70), the proof is completed. ∎

Concerning the exit point from ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆{\cal L}_{\lambda}, a simple consequence of Lemma 4.3 of [19] results into the following estimate.

Lemma 3.8.

Let ξλsubscript𝜉𝜆\xi_{\lambda} be given as in (2.24). Fix any C∈ℝ𝐶ℝC\in\mathbb{R}. Then, there exists M0subscript𝑀0M_{0} such that for all M>M0=M0​(λ)𝑀subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀0𝜆M>M_{0}=M_{0}(\lambda), we have

ℙ​(|Zλ​(C​N1/3)−ξλ​N|≥M​N2/3)≤K1​e−K2​M2ℙsubscript𝑍𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscript𝜉𝜆𝑁𝑀superscript𝑁23subscript𝐾1superscript𝑒subscript𝐾2superscript𝑀2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\left|Z_{\lambda}(CN^{1/3})-\xi_{\lambda}N\right|\geq MN^{2/3}\right)\leq K_{1}e^{-K_{2}M^{2}} (3.71)

for some constants K1=K1​(λ)subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾1𝜆K_{1}=K_{1}(\lambda) and K2=K2​(λ)subscript𝐾2subscript𝐾2𝜆K_{2}=K_{2}(\lambda), uniformly for all N𝑁N large enough.

Proof.

This results is a simple consequence of Lemma 4.3 of [19]. One shifts the origin to get the end-point ((1+γ)​N+c​N1/3,(1−γ)​N−c​N1/3)1𝛾𝑁𝑐superscript𝑁131𝛾𝑁𝑐superscript𝑁13((1+\gamma)N+cN^{1/3},(1-\gamma)N-cN^{1/3}) along the diagonal of the first quadrant as in the proof of Lemma 2.4. Then one can extend the line ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆{\cal L}_{\lambda} to ℒλ∞={(⌊λ−1λ​x⌋,x)|x∈ℤ}superscriptsubscriptℒ𝜆conditional-set𝜆1𝜆𝑥𝑥𝑥ℤ{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}=\left\{\left(\left\lfloor\tfrac{\lambda-1}{\lambda}x\right\rfloor,x\right)\big{|}x\in\mathbb{Z}\right\}. ℙ​(|Zλ​(C​N1/3)−ξλ​N|≥M​N2/3)≤ℙ​(|Zλ∞​(C​N1/3)−ξλ​N|≥M​N2/3).ℙsubscript𝑍𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscript𝜉𝜆𝑁𝑀superscript𝑁23ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝑍𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscript𝜉𝜆𝑁𝑀superscript𝑁23\mathbb{P}\left(\left|Z_{\lambda}(CN^{1/3})-\xi_{\lambda}N\right|\geq MN^{2/3}\right)\leq\mathbb{P}\left(\left|Z^{\infty}_{\lambda}(CN^{1/3})-\xi_{\lambda}N\right|\geq MN^{2/3}\right). (3.72)

In Lemma 4.3 of [19] we have exactly a Gaussian estimate (in the variable M𝑀M) of the latter, which finishes the proof. ∎

For the next result, we need to define the rescaled process for the stationary case,

The first result focus on a comparison between BN,λ±subscriptsuperscript𝐵plus-or-minus𝑁𝜆B^{\pm}_{N,\lambda} and LNresc,λsubscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}. The proof is geometric and uses the idea of Lemma 1 of [6].

Proposition 3.10.

Recall the good event defined in (3.48), namely

GN​(r):={Zstat,λ−​(C​N1/3)≤Zλ​(0)}∩{Zλ​(C​N1/3)≤Zstat,λ+​(0)}.assignsubscript𝐺𝑁𝑟superscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscript𝑍𝜆0subscript𝑍𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13superscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆0G_{N}(r):=\left\{Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{-}}(CN^{1/3})\leq Z_{\lambda}(0)\right\}\cap\{Z_{\lambda}(CN^{1/3})\leq Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{+}}(0)\}. (3.86)
Proof.

To prove this result, we use Lemma 3.5. We start by noting that for any two positive real numbers a<b𝑎𝑏a<b, the following hold

Zλ​(a)≤Zλ​(b)andZstat,λ±​(a)≤Zstat,λ±​(b)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑍𝜆𝑎subscript𝑍𝜆𝑏andsuperscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆plus-or-minus𝑎superscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆plus-or-minus𝑏\displaystyle Z_{\lambda}(a)\leq Z_{\lambda}(b)\quad\textrm{and}\quad Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{\pm}}(a)\leq Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{\pm}}(b) (3.87)

with probability 111. The way we prove these inequalities is by contradiction. If any of the inequalities in (3.87) does not hold, then the corresponding last passage paths would intersect at some point (lets say 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}) in between. In such case, the sections of the last passage paths intercepted between ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆{\cal L}_{\lambda} to 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} is actually the last passage path from ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆{\cal L}_{\lambda} to 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}. If a≠b𝑎𝑏a\neq b, then this would imply the existence of two different last passage paths πℒλ→𝐜subscript𝜋→subscriptℒ𝜆𝐜\pi_{\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}\to\mathbf{c}} (or, πℒλ→𝐜ϱsubscriptsuperscript𝜋italic-ϱ→subscriptℒ𝜆𝐜\pi^{\varrho}_{\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}\to\mathbf{c}}) from ℒλsubscriptℒ𝜆\mathcal{L}_{\lambda} to the point 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c}. As a consequence, the uniqueness of the last passage paths will be contradicted. Thus, the claim follows.

Now, notice that the condition (𝐢)𝐢\mathbf{(i)} Zλ​(C​N1/3)≤Zstat,λ+​(0)subscript𝑍𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13superscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆0Z_{\lambda}(CN^{1/3})\leq Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{+}}(0) implies

Zλ​(v​N1/3)≤Zλ​(C​N1/3)≤Zstat,λ+​(0)≤Zstat,λ+​(u​N1/3)subscript𝑍𝜆𝑣superscript𝑁13subscript𝑍𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13superscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆0superscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝑢superscript𝑁13\displaystyle Z_{\lambda}(vN^{1/3})\leq Z_{\lambda}(CN^{1/3})\leq Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{+}}(0)\leq Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{+}}(uN^{1/3}) (3.88)

whereas the condition (𝐢𝐢)𝐢𝐢\mathbf{(ii)} Zstat,λ−​(C​N1/3)≤Zλ​(0)superscript𝑍statsubscript𝜆𝐶superscript𝑁13subscript𝑍𝜆0Z^{{\rm stat},\lambda_{-}}(CN^{1/3})\leq Z_{\lambda}(0) implies

LNresc,λ​(u)−LNresc,λ​(v)subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁𝑣\displaystyle L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u)-L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(v) ≥BN,λ−​(u)−BN,λ−​(v)absentsubscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑁𝜆𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑁𝜆𝑣\displaystyle\geq B^{-}_{N,\lambda}(u)-B^{-}_{N,\lambda}(v)

from (3.88) and (3.89) respectively. Hence, the proof is completed. ∎

3.3.4 Proof of Proposition 3.2

Now, we turn to proving the Proposition 3.2. For this, we closely follows the arguments for tightness in [29], Theorem 1. First, we fix some large C>0𝐶0C>0. For any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, denote Aϵ:={maxu1,u2∈[−C,C]⁡|LNresc,λ​(u1)−LNresc,λ​(u2)|≥ϵ}assignsubscript𝐴italic-ϵsubscriptsubscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2𝐶𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁subscript𝑢1subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁subscript𝑢2italic-ϵA_{\epsilon}:=\{\max_{u_{1},u_{2}\in[-C,C]}\left|L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u_{1})-L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u_{2})\right|\geq\epsilon\}. The increments for the stationary case can be expressed, by Lemma 4.2 of [3], as

Lℒλ∞→P​(u​N1/3)λ±−Lℒλ∞→P​(0)λ±∼{∑i=1⌊u​N1/3⌋pi−∑i=1⌊u​N1/3⌋qi,for ​u>0,∑i=⌊u​N1/3⌋−1qi−∑i=⌊u​N1/3⌋−1pi,for ​u<0,\displaystyle L^{\lambda_{\pm}}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(uN^{1/3})}-L^{\lambda_{\pm}}_{{\cal L}_{\lambda}^{\infty}\to P(0)}\sim\left\{\begin{matrix}\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor uN^{1/3}\rfloor}p_{i}-\sum_{i=1}^{\lfloor uN^{1/3}\rfloor}q_{i},&\text{for }u>0,\\ \sum_{i=\lfloor uN^{1/3}\rfloor}^{-1}q_{i}-\sum_{i=\lfloor uN^{1/3}\rfloor}^{-1}p_{i},&\text{for }u<0,\end{matrix}\right. where pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}s (resp. qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}s) are i.i.d. Exp​(1−λ±)Exp1subscript𝜆plus-or-minus\mbox{Exp}(1-\lambda_{\pm}) (resp. Exp​(λ±)Expsubscript𝜆plus-or-minus\mbox{Exp}(\lambda_{\pm})) random variables.

and 2​λ±−1λ±​(1−λ±)=2​λ−1λ​(1−λ)+K​(λ)​r​N−1/32subscript𝜆plus-or-minus1subscript𝜆plus-or-minus1subscript𝜆plus-or-minus2𝜆1𝜆1𝜆𝐾𝜆𝑟superscript𝑁13\frac{2\lambda_{\pm}-1}{\lambda_{\pm}(1-\lambda_{\pm})}=\frac{2\lambda-1}{\lambda(1-\lambda)}+K(\lambda)rN^{-1/3} for K​(λ)=1−2​λ+2​λ2(1−λ)2​λ2+𝒪​(N−1/3)𝐾𝜆12𝜆2superscript𝜆2superscript1𝜆2superscript𝜆2𝒪superscript𝑁13K(\lambda)=\frac{1-2\lambda+2\lambda^{2}}{(1-\lambda)^{2}\lambda^{2}}+\mathcal{O}(N^{-1/3}). limN→∞ℬN,λ±​(u)⇒ℬ±​(u),⇒subscript→𝑁subscriptsuperscriptℬplus-or-minus𝑁𝜆𝑢superscriptℬplus-or-minus𝑢\lim_{N\to\infty}\mathcal{B}^{\pm}_{N,\lambda}(u)\Rightarrow\mathcal{B}^{\pm}(u), (3.96)

3.3.5 Proof of Proposition 3.3

We show (3.10) for v=0𝑣0v=0. The claim for general v∈[−C,C]𝑣𝐶𝐶v\in[-C,C] is simply obtained by replacing N𝑁N by N+v​N1/3𝑁𝑣superscript𝑁13N+vN^{1/3} in the proof and noting that (N+v​N1/3)1/3=N1/3+𝒪​(N−1/3)superscript𝑁𝑣superscript𝑁1313superscript𝑁13𝒪superscript𝑁13(N+vN^{1/3})^{1/3}=N^{1/3}+\mathcal{O}(N^{-1/3}). For any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, define the event A~ε={maxu∈[−C,C]⁡|LNresc,λ​(u)−LNresc,λ​(0)|≥ε}subscript~𝐴𝜀subscript𝑢𝐶𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁𝑢subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁0𝜀\widetilde{A}_{\varepsilon}=\{\max_{u\in[-C,C]}|L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(u)-L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(0)|\geq\varepsilon\}. Then

ℙ​(A~ε)≤ℙ​((GN​(r))c)+ℙ​(A~ε∩GN​(r)).ℙsubscript~𝐴𝜀ℙsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑁𝑟𝑐ℙsubscript~𝐴𝜀subscript𝐺𝑁𝑟\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{A}_{\varepsilon})\leq\mathbb{P}((G_{N}(r))^{c})+\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{A}_{\varepsilon}\cap G_{N}(r)). (3.98)

Applying Proposition 3.9 with r=N1/6−δ/2/C𝑟superscript𝑁16𝛿2𝐶r=N^{1/6-\delta/2}/\sqrt{C} leads to ℙ​((GN​(r))c)≤K1′​e−K2′​N1/3−δ/Cℙsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑁𝑟𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝐾′1superscript𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝐾′2superscript𝑁13𝛿𝐶\mathbb{P}((G_{N}(r))^{c})\leq K^{\prime}_{1}e^{-K^{\prime}_{2}N^{1/3-\delta}/C}. Thus it remains to get a bound of ℙ​(A~ε∩GN​(r))ℙsubscript~𝐴𝜀subscript𝐺𝑁𝑟\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{A}_{\varepsilon}\cap G_{N}(r)) for such choice of r𝑟r.

By Proposition 3.10, when the event GN​(r)subscript𝐺𝑁𝑟G_{N}(r) holds, then the increment of the (scaled) LPP are bounded by the ones of the stationary case with modified. This implies

ℙ​(A~ε∩GN​(r))≤ℙ​(maxu∈[−C,C]⁡BN,λ+​(u)≥ε)+ℙ​(minu∈[−C,C]⁡BN,λ−​(u)≤−ε).ℙsubscript~𝐴𝜀subscript𝐺𝑁𝑟ℙsubscript𝑢𝐶𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑁𝜆𝑢𝜀ℙsubscript𝑢𝐶𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝐵𝑁𝜆𝑢𝜀\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{A}_{\varepsilon}\cap G_{N}(r))\leq\mathbb{P}\left(\max_{u\in[-C,C]}B^{+}_{N,\lambda}(u)\geq\varepsilon\right)+\mathbb{P}\left(\min_{u\in[-C,C]}B^{-}_{N,\lambda}(u)\leq-\varepsilon\right). (3.99)

Recall the relation (3.97), namely N1/6​BN,λ±​(u)=ℬN,λ±​(u)+K​(λ)​u​r​N−1/6superscript𝑁16subscriptsuperscript𝐵plus-or-minus𝑁𝜆𝑢subscriptsuperscriptℬplus-or-minus𝑁𝜆𝑢𝐾𝜆𝑢𝑟superscript𝑁16N^{1/6}B^{\pm}_{N,\lambda}(u)=\mathcal{B}^{\pm}_{N,\lambda}(u)+K(\lambda)urN^{-1/6}. By the above choice of r𝑟r, the term K​(λ)​u​r​N−1/6∼N−δ/2→0similar-to𝐾𝜆𝑢𝑟superscript𝑁16superscript𝑁𝛿2→0K(\lambda)urN^{-1/6}\sim N^{-\delta/2}\to 0 as N→∞→𝑁N\to\infty. Therefore to bound (3.99) it is enough to bound

ℙ​(maxu∈[0,C]⁡ℬN,λ+​(u)≥ε​N1/6),ℙ​(maxu∈[0,C]−ℬN,λ−​(u)≥ε​N1/6)ℙsubscript𝑢0𝐶subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑁𝜆𝑢𝜀superscript𝑁16ℙsubscript𝑢0𝐶subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑁𝜆𝑢𝜀superscript𝑁16\mathbb{P}\left(\max_{u\in[0,C]}\mathcal{B}^{+}_{N,\lambda}(u)\geq\varepsilon N^{1/6}\right),\quad\mathbb{P}\left(\max_{u\in[0,C]}-\mathcal{B}^{-}_{N,\lambda}(u)\geq\varepsilon N^{1/6}\right) (3.100)

together with the same bound for u∈[−C,0]𝑢𝐶0u\in[-C,0]. ℬN,λ+subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑁𝜆\mathcal{B}^{+}_{N,\lambda} is a rescaled version of a sum of i.i.d. random centered variables with exponentially decaying tails, thus it is a (two-sided) martingale. Each of the bound is obtained in the same way, thus we write the details only for one of each. By Doob’s maximal inequality for the submartingale u↦eχ​ℬN,λ+​(u)maps-to𝑢superscript𝑒𝜒subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑁𝜆𝑢u\mapsto e^{\chi\mathcal{B}^{+}_{N,\lambda}(u)}, and minimizing over χ𝜒\chi, we get

ℙ​(maxu∈[0,C]⁡ℬN,λ+​(u)≥ε​N1/6)≤infχ>0exp⁡{−χ​s​N1/6+ln⁡𝔼​[exp⁡(χ​ℬN,λ+​(C))]}.ℙsubscript𝑢0𝐶subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑁𝜆𝑢𝜀superscript𝑁16subscriptinfimum𝜒0𝜒𝑠superscript𝑁16𝔼delimited-[]𝜒subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑁𝜆𝐶\mathbb{P}(\max_{u\in[0,C]}\mathcal{B}^{+}_{N,\lambda}(u)\geq\varepsilon N^{1/6})\leq\inf_{\chi>0}\exp\left\{-\chi sN^{1/6}+\ln\mathbbm{E}[\exp(\chi\mathcal{B}^{+}_{N,\lambda}(C))]\right\}. (3.101)

A simple computation gives

ln⁡𝔼​[exp⁡(χ​ℬN,λ+​(C))]=2​χ2​C​N1/3​(λ​(1−λ))−1+𝒪​(1).𝔼delimited-[]𝜒subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝑁𝜆𝐶2superscript𝜒2𝐶superscript𝑁13superscript𝜆1𝜆1𝒪1\ln\mathbbm{E}[\exp(\chi\mathcal{B}^{+}_{N,\lambda}(C))]=2\chi^{2}CN^{1/3}(\lambda(1-\lambda))^{-1}+\mathcal{O}(1). (3.102)

Plugging this into (3.101) and minimizing with respect to χ≥0𝜒0\chi\geq 0, we get

l.h.s. of​(3.101)≤K1​exp⁡(−K2​ε2​N1/3/C),l.h.s. of3.101subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2superscript𝜀2superscript𝑁13𝐶\textrm{l.h.s.~{}of}~{}(\ref{eq:MaximalInequality})\leq K_{1}\exp(-K_{2}\varepsilon^{2}N^{1/3}/C), (3.103)

where K1,K2subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2K_{1},K_{2} are two constants which depend on λ𝜆\lambda. This bound and the one above the probability on GN​(r)csubscript𝐺𝑁superscript𝑟𝑐G_{N}(r)^{c} implies (3.10).

Now we prove the inequality (3.11) for u=0𝑢0u=0. The inequality for general u∈[−C,C]𝑢𝐶𝐶u\in[-C,C] is obtained by substituting γ𝛾\gamma with γ+u​N−2/3𝛾𝑢superscript𝑁23\gamma+uN^{-2/3}. This time we are dealing with LPP between points which are“time-like”, i.e., where both coordinates of the end-point increase. However, since we are looking at a distance from the reference point P¯​(0,0)¯𝑃00\bar{P}(0,0) which is the of the same order as the case of (3.10), we can get a similar bound by using the analysis used to get (3.10) twice. Let us decompose the increments in (3.11) into a sum two increment the LPP between “space-like” points, i.e., with one coordinate increasing and the other decreasing. We have

LNresc,λ​(0,v)−LNresc,λ​(0,0)subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁0𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁00\displaystyle L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(0,v)-L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(0,0) =(LNresc,λ​(0,v)−LNresc,λ​((1−γ)​v,v))absentsubscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁0𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁1𝛾𝑣𝑣\displaystyle=\left(L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(0,v)-L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}((1-\gamma)v,v)\right) (3.104)
+(LNresc,λ​((1−γ)​v,v)−LNresc,λ​(0,0)).subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁1𝛾𝑣𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝐿resc𝜆𝑁00\displaystyle+\left(L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}((1-\gamma)v,v)-L^{{\rm resc},\lambda}_{N}(0,0)\right).

The first term in the r.h.s. of (3.104) is using (3.10). For the second term in the r.h.s. of (3.104) we get the same bound by applying exactly the same strategy for getting (3.10). Indeed, all the ingredients having two end-points used in the proof of (3.10) extends to points which are space-like: see Lemma 4.2 of [3] and the geometric proof of Proposition 3.10. The detailed proof do not require any new ideas, so we skip the details here.
